Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Foundations of Social and Ethical Responsibility Among Undergraduate Engineering Students: Comparing Across Time, Institutions, and Interventions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Recognizing the critical roles played by technical professionals in serving the public and addressing grand
challenges, many formal courses and programs have been created to promote professional responsibility
and ethical integrity among engineering graduates. Other interventions (e.g., service learning programs)
have been developed to more broadly challenge engineering and technology students to see themselves as
engaged citizens and community members. Yet there has been a lack of research on foundational
understandings of social and ethical responsibility among such students, including how these
understandings change over time and through participation in specific types of learning experiences.
Additional empirical evidence is needed to guide ongoing efforts to cultivate enhanced social and ethical
responsibility among future engineers, including by identifying and promoting specific interventions that
have the biggest positive impacts on students.

The proposed study responds to these gaps in the existing scholarship by asking the following research
questions: 1) What do engineering students perceive as responsible (and irresponsible) professional
conduct, and what do they perceive as socially just (and unjust) technical practices?, and 2) How do
foundational measures and understandings of social and ethical responsibility change during a four-year
engineering degree program, both in general and in relation to specific kinds of learning experiences? To
investigate these questions, a longitudinal mixed-method study design will collect and analyze
quantitative and qualitative data from undergraduate engineering students at four universities. To improve
transferability of results, these schools will represent a variety of institution types. Each collaborating
school also has large numbers of students in programs of interest, e.g., service-learning and intensified
ethics instruction. Further, the study will give priority to investigating differences in perceptions and
experiences among underrepresented student populations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Award Title: Collaborative Research: Foundations of Social and Ethical Responsibility Among Undergraduate Engineering Students: Comparing Across Time, Institutions, and Interventions

 

Federal Award ID: 1449370

Report Submission Period: 05/01/2019 to 09/30/2020

Background:

The development and assessment of ethics and social responsibility in engineering students has been of great interest to engineering educators, in part due to the important role engineers play in identifying and addressing some of society’s most pressing problems. However, prior research on engineering undergraduate students’ understandings of ethics and social responsibility used diverse methods and resulted in mixed and sometimes conflicting results.

Purpose:

The purpose of this project was to better understand how engineering undergraduate students perceive ethics and social responsibility and how those perceptions change over time and due to participation in certain experiences.

Approach:

To achieve the purpose of this project, we conducted a longitudinal, mixed-methods study at four U.S. universities. Undergraduate engineering students were surveyed three times over the project: during their first semester (Fall 2015), fifth semester (Fall 2017), and eighth semester (Spring 2019). The 226 students who completed all three surveys comprise the sample that was analyzed for longitudinal changes in their scores on eight quantitative scales, as well as differences by gender, university, and participation in various experiences. In addition, a subset of the participants was also interviewed twice during the project: during their second semester (Spring 2016) and eighth semester (Spring 2019) of their engineering studies. This interview data was analyzed to understand how students connect their ethical experiences and the outcomes they learned from those experiences, and how senior engineering students conceptualize engineering ethics.

Results:

This research established a baseline for the perceptions of ethics and social responsibility that first year engineering students possess when they begin their university studies. This included reporting on variability in these students’ views based on demographics, influences and learning experiences. Furthermore, by following these students over time, this project demonstrated that students modestly increased their

knowledge of ethics and ability to apply that knowledge in situations calling for them to exercise judgment during their four years as engineering undergraduates. They perceived the climates of their respective universities to be less ethical over time. When we compared students who did and did not participate in various types of experiences, we saw no interaction affects for most scales and most experiences, indicating that differences between participants and non-participants likely reflect a pattern of self-selection into certain activities. Finally, this project did not detect a culture of increasing disengagement among our participants as they progressed through their engineering education.

Conclusions:

Our findings hint at the difficulty of developing impactful ethics interventions, especially given that students arrive at university with a wealth of pre-existing knowledge and perceptions about ethics, morality, and related concerns. Decreasing perceptions of ethical climate are also a concern, and may be linked to competitive academic degree programs. A positive finding is that we did not detect a culture of increasing disengagement in engineering students over time. Finally, this project provided two undergraduate students with experience in qualitative social science research methods. Due to its status as a collaborative project, it also provided the PI with experience in the management of large, multi-institutional research projects.
